author: By Katie Robertson
title: Piers Morgan signs a new deal with his first boss, Rupert Murdoch.
description: The television host's last job came to an end when he stormed off the set. Under the new deal, he will host a show and write a column.
content: Piers Morgan, the British TV host and onetime tabloid editor, is back in the Murdoch fold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Historian of Race in America Gets an Unusual Four-Book Deal
description: Martha S. Jones, a professor at Johns Hopkins University, will write four books for Basic Books, starting with an exploration of the history and legacy of slavery’s sexual violence.
content: The historian Martha S. Jones has a nose for writing deeply researched histories that land in the middle of the rough and tumble of our national politics — sometimes deliberately, sometimes not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Scully
title: Let the Bison Be
description: The National Park Service should stop a planned cull of these animals in Grand Canyon National Park.
content: PHOENIX — In politics, issues of true importance aren’t always the ones that consume our attention. My candidate for the most underrated of all public concerns is the treatment of animals, an issue as revealing as any about our character and sense of fairness. If you want hard evidence to track the moral progress of humanity, watch how we deal with other creatures who are defenseless against our power and will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: A.O.C.’s Met Gala Designer Explains Her ‘Tax the Rich’ Dress
description: “For us it was about delivering a message.”
content: The day after the gown she designed for Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez made global headlines, Aurora James was reflecting on the fact that she didn’t see many other Black women designers represented at the Met Gala, which this year was meant to celebrate “American independence.” (There were several Black men designers in attendance as guests or dressing guests.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘In Balanchine’s Classroom’ Review: Teaching the Ineffable
description: Former ballet dancers grasp at words to describe the genius of George Balanchine in this charming documentary.
content: In mathematics, there was Newton; in psychology, there was Freud; and in American ballet, George Balanchine was a foundational genius. He was a Georgian choreographer born in Russia who found prominence with the Ballets Russes in Paris, and moved from Europe to the United States in 1933. There, Balanchine helped to found the highly influential School of American Ballet and New York City Ballet, and he used those institutions to revolutionize the style of dance that was performed in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed will re-examine ethics rules after trades by two officials drew scrutiny.
description: Senator Elizabeth Warren urged tougher restrictions after disclosures that two regional Federal Reserve presidents bought and sold stocks and real estate-tied assets last year.
content: The Federal Reserve is poised to overhaul the rules regarding what its officials are allowed to invest in and trade after disclosures last week showed that two of the central bank’s officials were active in markets in 2020, drawing an outcry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Los Últimos Frikis’ Review: Keep On Rocking in Cuba
description: The hook of this documentary is the spectacle of a revolutionary government that can’t abide the rebellion of rock without bureaucratic oversight.
content: In the 1990s Diony Arce, lead singer of the Cuban heavy metal group Zeus, was jailed for six years. That act of repression raises the stakes in Nicholas Brennan’s scrappy film “Los Últimos Frikis” and makes it more than your average documentary about middle-aged rockers attempting a comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Are Zoom Weddings Virtually Over?
description: Couples turned to livestreaming platforms to share their nuptials last year. Now, smaller in-person weddings with a virtual option offer the best of both worlds.
content: When Peter Tinaglia, 44, and Andy Maliszewski, 52, proposed to each other in Maui in 2014, they figured they had plenty of time to figure out how and when they would get married. They could invite 20 people or 200. They could have a D.J. or a band. Zoom weddings and a looming pandemic were not on their radar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Pascal Siakam Has Heard the Rumors, but He’s Ready to Lead
description: Frustrated by not feeling like he was his team’s focus, and slowed by illness and injury, Siakam believes his future is in Toronto. And that the future is bright.
content: In the fall of 2019, Pascal Siakam was riding high. He had just finished his third N.B.A. season and was well on his way to becoming basketball royalty in Canada, having just helped lead the Toronto Raptors to their first championship, alongside Kyle Lowry and Kawhi Leonard. Siakam was awarded a maximum contract extension, which gave him the status — at least financially — reserved for stars. He rewarded that faith from the Raptors by making his first career All-Star team that season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen and Kate Conger
title: What the Privacy Battle Upending the Internet Means for You
description: Get ready for more random ads online, higher prices and subscriptions galore. But your privacy concerns may still not fade.
content: The internet is changing, including how much we pay for content and the ads and brands we see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘I Am Not Alone’ Review: Looking Back on an Uprising
description: This documentary offers a play-by-play account of nonviolent protests that shook up politics in Armenia in 2018.
content: In 2018, the president of Armenia, Serzh Sargsyan, facing term limits, sought to stay in power by having members of his party in the country’s parliament elect him as the prime minister; a constitutional referendum in 2015 had transferred most of the president’s powers to that position. Critics of the right-wing Sargsyan saw that as an autocratic move. In protest, Nikol Pashinyan — a Parliament member and former political prisoner and newspaper editor — started what became a nationwide movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Alex Murdaugh Charged With Fraud After Asking Former Client to Kill Him
description: But Mr. Murdaugh, part of a prominent family of South Carolina lawyers, has denied any involvement in the unsolved killings of his wife and son in June.
content: The prominent South Carolina lawyer whose life has unraveled in the months since his wife and son were fatally shot was arrested on Thursday after he admitted to trying to stage his own murder earlier this month, but he maintained that he had no involvement in the killing of his family.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Russians Vote, Resignation, Anger and Fear of a Post-Putin Unknown
description: Many in Russia say they are fed up with corruption, stagnant wages and rising prices. But they worry, as one man said, that “if things start to change, there will be blood.”
content: She walked into the cafe wearing a face mask that read, “I’m not afraid, and don’t you be afraid.” A man in a leather jacket followed her in, looked at her as she sat down next to me, then disappeared. Another man, in a vest and gray cap, waited outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Bryan
title: How British Crime Dramas Became Appointment TV
description: In Britain, a series of recent big budget BBC thrillers have drawn record viewing figures, thanks to a combination of suspenseful writing and weekly episodes.
content: LONDON — Crime shows have been a popular British export for decades, but a recent batch of big budget, critically acclaimed BBC thrillers have drawn record weekly viewing figures here, keeping viewers transfixed in a state of constant, existential dread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Elsie Chen
title: China says it has fully vaccinated 1 billion people.
description: The country stepped closer to its goal of inoculating 80 percent of its population of 1.4 billion by the end of the year.
content: China said on Thursday that it had fully inoculated 1 billion people, a milestone for the world’s most populous country that brings it closer to its goal of vaccinating 80 percent of its population by the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pols
title: They Survived, They Recovered (Mostly) ... What Next?
description: Three new memoirs traverse the rocky terrain between illness and everyday life.
content: THE NIGHT THE LIGHTS WENT OUT
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Drug Plan Fails, Signaling Thorny Path for Democrats’ $3.5 Trillion Bill
description: Senior Democrats said they could still preserve elements of their plan to lower prescription drug prices, but they have little room for defections, and divisions remain on that and other issues.
content: WASHINGTON — A Democratic plan to lower prescription drug prices as part of the party’s $3.5 trillion social policy package failed in a House committee on Wednesday after moderates refused to support it, highlighting internal divisions that could complicate the legislation’s path to enactment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Zach Montague
title: The White House offers a call to Nicki Minaj to discuss vaccine safety.
description: The rapper did not attend the Met Gala this week because she has not been vaccinated.
content: After the rapper Nicki Minaj questioned the efficacy of the Covid-19 vaccine in a Twitter post this week, the White House confirmed on Wednesday that it had offered her a call with a doctor to answer questions about the safety of the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Peeing in the Ocean
description: Newlyweds squabble over using nature as your toilet.
content: Dan writes: Naomi and I were married in June. We love beach vacations, but it bugs me that Naomi is cool with peeing in the ocean. She is mindful of people around her. But I think she knows it bugs me and enjoys creeping me out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: balderdash
description: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: At Least 9 Drown Swimming Off the Coast of Southern France
description: The victims had ventured into the waves at various beaches despite high seas stirred up by strong winds that formed perilous underwater swells.
content: PARIS — At least nine people have been swept out to sea and drowned off the southern coast of France after high seas stirred up by strong winds created dangerous swells that caught the swimmers by surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Wife of a Spy’ Review: Trust or Fear in Love and War?
description: In this latest work by Kiyoshi Kurosawa, a Japanese couple’s relationship is shaped by the forces of churning nationalism that surround it.
content: There are a lot of commonplace story elements in “Wife of a Spy.” Childhood friends divided by the beating of war drums. A glib, secretive husband and a distrustful wife. And so on. Combined with its period setting — the movie begins in 1940, at a silk inspection center in Kobe where a British fellow is picked up for questioning — viewers might therefore expect a fairly conventional dramatic thriller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Apple and Facebook Are Coming for Your Face Next
description: Brace yourself for an onslaught of devices that connect your eyes to the digital world.
content: It is difficult to avoid sounding vulgar, somehow, when discussing the future of facial computing. There is something inescapably crude, isn’t there, about the prospect of everyone walking around with computers on our faces?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Cry Macho’ Review: The Good, the Bad and the Poultry
description: In his latest film, Clint Eastwood drives across Mexico with a troubled young man and a combative rooster.
content: Mike Milo is a former rodeo rider and horse trainer — an ornery old cuss with a complicated past and a soft spot for children and animals. He’s a grouch but also a professional, with a deep knowledge of his craft and a flinty sense of honor. To put it in simpler terms, he’s played by Clint Eastwood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Where Redistricting Stands in 14 States
description: We took a look at possible shifts in partisan power as redistricting maps start to trickle out.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Spying That Changed Big Tech
description: The backlash against the industry traces back partly to the Snowden revelations.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Sept. 22, 2021
description: How has the “normal” amount of precipitation changed across the United States?
content: These graphs, which are data maps called choropleths, show the 30-year precipitation levels compared to the 20th century precipitation average for the time periods 1901-1930, 1931-1960, 1961-1990 and 1991-2020. The data was gathered from 15,000 weather stations from around the country, including more than 8,000 stations operated by volunteers. Started in 1890, this volunteer effort is one of the oldest and largest citizen-science projects anywhere. The graphs appeared elsewhere in the NYTimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Anderson Cooper Wishes His Parents and Truman Capote Could Reconcile Over Dinner
description: “They stopped speaking to him after he wrote some pretty cruel stuff about my mom in a story published in Esquire in 1975. I wouldn’t want Truman to stay very long though, and he couldn’t have any alcohol. Actually let’s make it Truman circa 1966, not the bloated Truman of 1975.”
content: “They stopped speaking to him after he wrote some pretty cruel stuff about my mom in a story published in Esquire in 1975,” says the CNN anchor Anderson Cooper, whose new book, with Katherine Howe, is “Vanderbilt: The Rise and Fall of an American Dynasty.” “I wouldn’t want Truman to stay very long though, and he couldn’t have any alcohol. Actually let’s make it Truman circa 1966, not the bloated Truman of 1975.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Venezuela’s Judicial System Abets Repression, Says U.N. Rights Panel
description: An investigation found that political interference pushed judges and prosecutors to provide legal cover for killings, torture and other abuses.
content: GENEVA — Rather than upholding civil rights, Venezuela’s judicial system has served as an instrument of repression at the hands of political leaders and the security services at their disposal, United Nations human rights experts said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: R. Kelly Pressed Victims to Write Letters Absolving Him, Prosecutors Say
description: Many of Mr. Kelly’s accusers say he pressured them to write letters that said he was innocent of the sexual abuse that they now say he committed.
content: Five months after R. Kelly’s 2019 arrest, federal agents searching a locked safe in a Chicago storage facility discovered a stack of the singer’s personal papers in protective sleeves. Among them: a seven-page handwritten letter from a woman who began living with Mr. Kelly when she was 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Hamilton’ Cancels Atlanta Performance Over Covid Concerns
description: After some members of a touring company tested positive for the coronavirus, Wednesday night’s show did not go on.
content: “Hamilton” canceled a performance in Atlanta Wednesday night after some members of a touring company tested positive for the coronavirus, and the show was unable to get test results for other company members before curtain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘The Journey of a 9/11 Tree’
description: It has been 20 years since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. What can we learn from the story of a single tree that was wounded on that tragic day?
content: As the nation and world commemorates the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, we present a short and simple but powerful film from 2015, “The Journey of a 9/11 Tree.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith and Arthur Lubow
title: Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: Check out Alvaro Barrington’s Neo-Expressionist paintings with a political edge; and Jill Freedman’s visceral photos of street cops from the ’70s.
content: Alvaro Barrington’s Manhattan debut of big, bright, sometimes object-laden paintings on burlap is portentously titled “Garvey 1: Birth — The Quiet Storm” and should be taken as a statement of intent, wide-ranging talent and exuberant ambition. Ignore the overreaching news release at the front desk which ties the artist’s life to that of Marcus Garvey, because of “similarities in their migratory paths,” and consider the work, which is by turn beautiful, awkward and slightly laughable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Philippines Is Defiant as Hague Court Announces Full Drug War Inquiry
description: The International Criminal Court will investigate the killings of thousands under President Rodrigo Duterte. His lawyer says it has no authority to do so.
content: MANILA — A lawyer for President Rodrigo Duterte said on Thursday that International Criminal Court representatives would be denied entry to the Philippines, a day after the Hague-based tribunal authorized a full investigation into Mr. Duterte’s bloody war on drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: For Some, Afghanistan Outcome Affirms a Warning: Beware the Blob
description: The chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan exposed the shortcomings of views within the foreign policy establishment, also known as ‘The Blob.’
content: First there was the Biden administration’s withdrawal from Afghanistan. Then there was the chorus of disapproval. And then, as is so often the case in American foreign policy, there was the Blob.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Blue Bayou’ Review: No Direction Home
description: Justin Chon’s immigration melodrama counters its soggy storytelling with deeply felt performances.
content: “Blue Bayou” opens on a close-up of Antonio LeBlanc (played by the writer and director, Justin Chon) interviewing for a job. Born in South Korea and raised from a child by adoptive parents in Louisiana, Antonio needs to supplement his income as a tattoo artist to support his wife (Alicia Vikander), his stepdaughter, Jessie (Sydney Kowalske), and an imminent new baby. It is immediately clear, though, that the unseen interviewer is less concerned with Antonio’s felony convictions than his origins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Joan Washington, Dialect Coach to the Stars, Dies at 74
description: She taught Barbra Streisand, Penélope Cruz and countless other performers how to sound like someone else.
content: Joan Washington, an acclaimed dialect coach who taught Penélope Cruz to sound Greek, Jessica Chastain to sound Israeli and an entire cast of British actors to speak like Brooklyn Jews, died on Sept. 2 at her home in Avening, England. She was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and Justin J Wee
title: Bringing Broadway Spectacle Back to Life
description: How five big returning shows, including “The Phantom of the Opera” and “Moulin Rouge!,” have retuned, restored and restarted their signature effects.
content: On March 12, 2020, Broadway went dark. Curtains down. Ghost lights on. Doors locked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Have You Ever Felt Too Much Pressure to Win?
description: How did you feel when Simone Biles and Naomi Osaka withdrew from recent competitions? Have you ever made a similar decision?
content: Do we place too much pressure on young competitors?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Pizza-Paved Path to the Far Side of the Covid Pandemic
description: With vaccines, walk the walk. It’s delicious.
content: I can rage about the number of Americans who refuse to get Covid vaccines and who, as a result, have prevented this country’s vaccination rate from rising to the level where people are as safe as possible and the economy less encumbered. And I’ve raged, believe me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: Joe Manchin Doesn’t Know What He’s Missing
description: Infrastructure isn’t about the price tag. It’s about what the money gets us.
content: Democrats are in the thick of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Pao
title: The Elizabeth Holmes Trial Is a Wake-Up Call for Sexism in Tech
description: In tech, brash male founders are allowed to overpromise and underdeliver, time and again. Not so much for women.
content: Elizabeth Holmes followed the Silicon Valley playbook to a T. She was focused and ambitious. She had a compelling vision to help humanity with technology for blood tests, and her ambition, she said, was driven by a personal fear of needles. She fit the pattern of the young, brilliant college dropout, even dressing like Steve Jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ruly Carpenter, 81, Dies; Owned the Phillies’ First Championship Team
description: Distressed by soaring salaries, he sold the team a year after they beat Kansas City in the 1980 World Series. “We hoped common sense would prevail,’’ he said. “But it didn’t.”
content: Ruly Carpenter, the third-generation owner of the Philadelphia Phillies, who in 1981 sold the team a year after they won their first World Series, saying he was troubled by the rising cost of player salaries, died on Monday at his home in Montchanin, Del., near Wilmington. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Is Self-Awareness a Mirage?
description: We know what we’re feeling, just not how and why we got here.
content: One of the most unsettling findings of modern psychology is that we often don’t know why we do what we do. You can ask somebody: Why’d you choose that house? Or why’d you marry that person? Or why’d you go to graduate school? People will concoct some plausible story, but often they really have no idea why they chose what they did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: The Best Everyday Dals
description: These nourishing pots of lentils can be as simple or as extravagant as you’d like.
content: My grandmother puts a handful of whole peanuts along with the split pigeon peas in her Gujarati-style toor dal, so they boil until they’re a little tender and plump. And my mum fries garlic, green chiles and cumin seeds in ghee to season a pot of simmered, salted split mung.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Emotionally charged quilts, a punk Art Deco hotel — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Where Was This Money When I Made My Down Payment?
description: A reader is hurt by her parents’ decision to help finance her sister’s path to homeownership but not her own.
content: I am in my late 30s and have a good relationship with my parents. We speak on the phone weekly. Last Sunday, my mother informed me that they gave my sister a chunk of money to help with a down payment on a house. She told me I wouldn’t receive a matching sum because my husband and I already own a house and his parents gave us a generous gift when we were buying it. My parents aren’t wealthy, so I understand their decision. Still, it stings! I think my parents are making assumptions about my financial position. I also believe their choice to give money to my younger sister is a declaration of greater love for her. Should I bring this up again?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Greenwich, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: With a Rare ‘Oedipe,’ the Paris Opera Pulls Together
description: Staged by the playwright and director Wajdi Mouawad, Enescu’s opera helps inaugurate a new era for the storied company.
content: PARIS — Ahead of rehearsals for his staging of George Enescu’s “Oedipe” at the Paris Opera, the playwright and director Wajdi Mouawad did something unusual. He put together a glossary of all the obscure references in the libretto — like “the water of Castalia,” a sacred spring in Delphi — and sent it to the chorus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Interactive Shadowboxes Breathe Life Into the Legacies of Village Artists
description: “Village Voices,” an interactive outdoor exhibition, honors Billie Holiday, Charlie Parker, Jackson Pollock and more.
content: At St. Mark’s Church in-the-Bowery, there hangs a shadowbox — a square, three-dimensional display case — containing a black and white photograph of Charlie Parker. His lips are pursed, his fingers are poised and he’s playing his saxophone with deep concentration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danez Smith and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: waiting on you to die so i can be myself
description: In this world filled, sometimes, with more breakdowns than breaks, it feels sometimes an anachronism to hear anybody say they love somebody deeply.
content: Two lines keep bringing me back: “i’m waiting for a few folks/i love dearly to die so i can be myself.” In this world filled, sometimes, with more breakdowns than breaks, it feels sometimes an anachronism to hear anybody say they love somebody deeply. Then it hurts a bit to remember all that comes with love. Who among us ain’t been a bit afraid to be they whole entire self? Who doesn’t understand that desire? Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Politics of Mapmaking
description: Everyone expected New York's redistricting process to be messy, but it turned into a partisan squabble  from the very beginning.
content: It’s Thursday. We’ll look at how a state commission released not one but two sets of maps — one Democratic, the other Republican — for Congress, the Assembly and the State Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: How Biden’s Economic Executive Order Aims to Improve Travel
description: In July, President Biden issued an executive order that included a call to make consumer-friendly changes in the travel industry. We asked experts to weigh in on the prospects for change.
content: In his July 9 executive order to promote competition in the American economy, President Biden took on banking, tech and pharmaceutical giants, noting that consumers often pay too much for services in the wake of industry consolidation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: A New Level of Ambition in Art by 3 Women
description: Three gallery shows of new work by veteran artists who happen to be women highlight their different ways and means of development, and the way they are taking new risks.
content: Autumn tends to be a great time in New York City’s art world. The weather can be superb. There’s a back-to-school excitement as galleries reopen, sometimes at new addresses, usually with new shows. Even having art fairs arrive inconveniently early this year, during Labor Day week, didn’t dampen things.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: If you’re looking for escapist reading, this week’s recommended books won’t help. But if you want a cleareyed and sometimes rousing look at the state of the world today, settle right in: We’ve got books about the Mexican drug trade and America’s efforts to combat it (“The Dope,” by Benjamin T. Smith), along with an argument that modern warfare is too easy (Samuel Moyn’s “Humane”) and a memoir by a key figure in Donald Trump’s first impeachment (Alexander Vindman’s “Here, Right Matters”). We’ve got a hardscrabble immigration memoir from Qian Julie Wang, “Beautiful Country,” and two books exploring aspects of technology: Meghan O’Gieblyn’s “God, Human, Animal, Machine” and Tom Standage’s “A Brief History of Motion.” And in fiction, we recommend three debut novels about characters trying to make the best of sometimes dire circumstances: “Paris Is a Party, Paris Is a Ghost,” by David Hoon Kim, “Three Rooms,” by Jo Hamya, and “The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois,” by the accomplished poet Honorée Fanonne Jeffers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The Best (and Worst) Metro Areas for Electric Cars
description: All places are not equal when it comes to the infrastructure that supports electric vehicles.
content: Even as more workers free themselves from the daily commute in the new work-from-home economy, demand for cars in the United States is soaring, in part because of low interest rates and government stimulus checks. Fortunately for the environmentally minded consumer, more automakers are pushing into the electric-car market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: In an Era of Throwers, a Pitcher Remains
description: Still an ace at 40, Adam Wainwright of the St. Louis Cardinals is having his best season in years. His secret? “It starts with a game of catch.”
content: Adam Wainwright is having fun, as expected from a 40-year-old pitcher in a renaissance season. More pointedly, though, he made a decision to have fun six months ago, back in spring training, when his schedule could have annoyed him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Clare Toeniskoetter, Neena Pathak, Diana Nguyen, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The United States v. Elizabeth Holmes
description: The trial of the Theranos founder throws a spotlight on tech stardom, start-up culture and Silicon Valley hubris.
content: When Elizabeth Holmes founded Theranos, the blood testing start-up, she was held up as one of the next great tech innovators. She cultivated her public image with a deep voice, an intense stare and a uniform of black turtlenecks meant to evoke Steve Jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: California Judge Cuéllar to Lead Influential Think Tank
description: An immigrant and Obama White House aide, Mr. Cuéllar takes over an institution with close ties to President Biden.
content: WASHINGTON — The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, an influential Washington-based think tank, has appointed Justice Mariano-Florentino Cuéllar of California’s Supreme Court as its new president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Lucid Motors beats Tesla in range, going 520 miles on a charge, the E.P.A. says.
description: Tesla, which makes about two-thirds of electric vehicles sold in the United States, has long produced the cars with the best range.
content: Lucid Motors, a start-up automaker, has unseated Tesla, the dominant maker of electric cars, as the producer of the electric vehicle that can travel farthest on a single charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: 16 New and Upcoming Young Adult Books to Watch For
description: There are novels about Black boys finding joy, nervy thrillers, fantasies filled with magic, angsty romances and much, much more.
content: Finch Kelly is a transgender teenager whose dream is to go to Georgetown University, the first step in his plan to become the country’s first openly transgender member of Congress. He believes the ticket into Georgetown is winning the National Speech & Debate Tournament, but when he finds out the year’s topic — should transgender students in public schools be allowed to use the bathroom of their choice? — he has to decide if arguing against his own humanity is a price he is willing to pay to achieve his dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia to Open New Frontier in Space, Shooting First Full-Length Movie
description: Racing to beat NASA, an actress and a film director will blast off next month for the International Space Station, where they will film “The Challenge.”
content: MOSCOW — The first satellite in space, the first dog, the first man, the first woman and now — if all goes as planned — the first movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: An Interview With Our New Politics Editor
description: David Halbfinger comes to the job after almost four years heading The Times’s Jerusalem bureau. “I just can’t think of a more important way that I could contribute,” he said of his new post.
content: David Halbfinger recently returned to the United States after nearly four years as The New York Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief, a role widely considered one of the most sensitive jobs in journalism. His next challenge is proving to be just as big a test: Heading the paper’s U.S. political coverage during a time of partisan division and what looks to be a bare-knuckle midterm election in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar, Isabelia Herrera and Gregory Cowles
title: For National Hispanic Heritage Month, 11 Recent Books on Latino Life
description: Reflections on brownness, stories about migrant workers and queer immigrants, postcolonial poems — and more.
content: National Hispanic Heritage Month, a celebration that runs from Sept. 15 to Oct. 15, captures a period covering seven different independence days across Latin America. In recent years, however, the celebration has prompted Latinos in the United States to look inward, grappling with issues of representation, colorism and sexuality. To better understand these perspectives, here are 11 recent books that provide a glimpse into distinct corners of contemporary Latino life in the United States:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: 5 New Biographies to Read This Season
description: The first major study of Oscar Wilde in decades, the conclusion of a “magisterial” series on Pablo Picasso, and more.
content: It’s been over 30 years since the last major biography of Wilde, and Sturgis draws on new material and research (including a full transcript of his catastrophic libel trial). “The established persona of Oscar Wilde — the unflappable, epigrammatic Aesthete — is so compelling that it is hard not to be seduced by it,” Sturgis writes, as he sets out to restore Wilde to his era and the facts of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar and Joumana Khatib
title: 11 New Works of Nonfiction to Read This Season
description: A deeply reported look at the woman behind Roe vs. Wade, an investigation of lawbreaking animals, another hilarious essay collection from Phoebe Robinson — and more.
content: In 2018, the Arlee Warriors, a boy’s high school basketball team on Montana’s Flathead Indian reservation, was in the midst of a buzzing championship run as its town reeled from a cluster of suicides. Streep, who previously profiled the team for The New York Times Magazine, delves into the lives of the players, the town’s collective trauma and the therapeutic power of basketball in Arlee, where the sport “occupies emotional terrain somewhere between escape and religion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Fiasco,’ a Look at How America Got to Where It Is
description: An absorbing account of the Iran-contra scandal avoids lecturing, but the lessons are unavoidable.
content: One of the anecdotes studded like candied fruit throughout “Fiasco,” a six-episode documentary about the Iran-contra affair, involves the C.I.A.’s prepping of Ronald Reagan for his first summit with Mikhail Gorbachev in 1985. Knowing that reading was not Reagan’s preferred method of absorbing information, the agency prepared, to his delight, a film biography of the Soviet leader with whom he was about to negotiate the fate of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: French Forces Kill an ISIS Leader in Sahara, Macron Says
description: Adnan Abu Walid al-Sahraoui’s group claimed responsibility for an attack that killed four U.S. soldiers in Niger. President Emmanuel Macron also blamed the group for killing French charity workers.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France announced Wednesday that French military forces had killed the leader of the Islamic State in the Greater Sahara.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Saint-Narcisse’ Review: A Classic Romance Between Twin Flames
description: In this Bruce LaBruce melodrama, two twins, both alike in indecency, fall in love.
content: The Canadian filmmaker Bruce LaBruce is best known for his provocative spins on modern sexuality, but his latest is a semiclassical affair. The melodrama “Saint-Narcisse” presents an interpretation of the Greek myth of Narcissus, the beautiful youth who pined after his own reflection. Of course, this is mythology by way of 1970s pornography; incest and Catholic perversion abound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar and Lara Jakes
title: U.S. and Egypt Put Improving Egypt’s Human Rights on the Agenda
description: Both countries took steps aimed at improving Egypt’s poor human rights record, but rights advocates found them short of the mark.
content: CAIRO — Within days of each other, the United States and Egypt announced moves this week that, for the first time in years, would put human rights on the agenda in Egypt, a country that has become notorious for jailing activists, targeting journalists and squashing free speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gal Beckerman
title: For His Next Act, Anthony Doerr Wrote a Book About Everything
description: The author of “All the Light We Cannot See” has a new novel, “Cloud Cuckoo Land,” that seeks to tell a sprawling story linking past, present and future.
content: KETCHUM, Idaho — Anthony Doerr kept apologizing for the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: On Death Row Half His Life, Oklahoma Man May Be a Step Closer to Release
description: A panel has recommended that Julius Jones’s sentence in a 1999 murder be commuted. His case, which has prompted public demonstrations and celebrity advocacy, is now on the governor’s desk.
content: A man on death row in Oklahoma could be one step closer to being released from prison after the state’s pardon and parole board recommended this week that his sentence be commuted, sending the case to the governor’s desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Week 2 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: Daniel Jones and the Giants head to Washington; Josh Allen and the Bills try to bounce back in Miami; and Patrick Mahomes and the Chiefs aim to maintain a winning streak against Baltimore.
content: Last-second field goals. Teams flooding the field for congratulatory hugs before the game officially ended. Nine underdogs upsetting their opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: In Submarine Deal With Australia, U.S. Counters China but Enrages France
description: The reaction signals a widening rift among Western allies over China. French officials accused President Biden of acting like his predecessor.
content: PARIS — President Biden’s announcement of a deal to help Australia deploy nuclear-powered submarines has strained the Western alliance, infuriating France and foreshadowing how the conflicting American and European responses to confrontation with China may redraw the global strategic map.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Sian Proctor is the first Black woman to pilot a spacecraft.
description: The community college professor has long pursued her dream of being an astronaut.
content: Sian Proctor, 51, is a community college professor from Tempe, Ariz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: ‘Light and Desire’ Review: Express Yourself, if You Can
description: In Colleen Thomas’s work at New York Live Arts, created and performed by women, the sense of pent-up release was strong.
content: A smiling woman opens her mouth to speak, but before the words get out, she stops. Some invisible force, apparently internalized, has silenced her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Indonesian President Found to Be Negligent Over Jakarta Pollution
description: A court ruled in a lawsuit that President Joko Widodo and six other top officials had neglected to fulfill citizens’ rights to clean air and ordered them to improve the air quality in the capital.
content: JAKARTA, Indonesia — A court ruled on Thursday that President Joko Widodo and six other top officials had neglected to fulfill citizens’ rights to clean air and ordered them to improve the poor air quality in Jakarta, the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Hwaida Saad
title: With Fuel from Iran, Hezbollah Steps In Where Lebanon Has Failed
description: The militant group trucked more than 1 million gallons of diesel into Lebanon, flouting U.S. sanctions and billing itself as savior to a suffering population.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Hezbollah militant group said it trucked more than a million gallons of Iranian diesel fuel into Lebanon from Syria on Thursday, celebrating the move as a way of spiting the United States while bringing much-needed aid to a country nearly paralyzed by fuel shortages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: 20 New Works of Fiction to Read This Season
description: New novels from Jonathan Franzen and Anthony Doerr, a political thriller by Hillary Clinton and Louise Penny, a Korean murder mystery — and more.
content: Here’s a third smart, sexy novel from Rooney, who received widespread acclaim for her first two, “Conversations With Friends” and “Normal People.” This book has a clear autobiographical bent: Alice is a young novelist who has rocketed to worldwide fame. Her close friendship with Eileen anchors the book, with their email exchanges alighting on everything from political and social upheaval to their romantic lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan and Joumana Khatib
title: Get to Know Your Favorite Actors and Artists a Little Better
description: Watch for new memoirs from Gabrielle Union and Alan Cumming, Jamie Foxx’s reflections on parenthood, Patricia Highsmith’s diaries and more.
content: Readers of Union’s first book, “We’re Going to Need More Wine,” know the actor and activist is a brave, funny and irreverent storyteller. In this collection of stories from her life, Union goes there again, whether she’s consulting a Hollywood shaman, suffering from constipation at an Atlanta strip club or celebrating the birth of her long-awaited daughter, Kaavia. If “We’re Going to Need More Wine” was her first date with readers, “You Got Anything Stronger” is the first weekend away together, Union explains: “Because just as you think you know someone, it turns out you actually have no idea who a person is until you’ve traveled with them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Prisoners of the Ghostland’ Review: Going Nuclear
description: If the combination of Nicolas Cage and the director Sion Sono suggests a special kind of lunacy, this sunbaked samurai western more than delivers.
content: With hindsight, we should have known that a collaboration between Nicolas Cage and the dashingly eccentric Japanese filmmaker Sion Sono was only a matter of time. Yet now that “Prisoners of the Ghostland” is here, it seems equally apparent that doubling the weirdness can, for the audience, produce ten times the head-scratching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Giulia Heyward
title: Idaho allows overwhelmed hospitals across the state to ration care if necessary.
description: “We don’t have enough resources to adequately treat the patients in our hospitals, whether you are there for Covid-19 or a heart attack or because of a car accident,” said a top state health official.
content: With its hospitals struggling to cope with a flood of patients, Idaho officials activated “crisis standards of care” across the state on Thursday, allowing overwhelmed facilities to ration treatment if needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: African public health experts call for the U.N. General Assembly to speed the delivery of vaccines.
description: Only 2 percent of doses administered globally so far have been given in Africa, where one-sixth of the world’s people live, according to the W.H.O.
content: As world leaders prepared to gather at the United Nations General Assembly, African public health experts called on Thursday for action to speed up delivery of Covid-19 vaccines to their continent, where according to the World Health Organization, only 3.6 percent of people have been fully inoculated against the disease so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: In the Waves
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of. Another option? Write from the point of view of one of the people in the image. What might this person be thinking and feeling?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Ida Nudel, ‘Angel’ to Soviet Jews Seeking to Flee, Dies at 90
description: During the Cold War, she fought for the rights of others and waged a 16-year fight of her own for an exit visa to Israel. She finally won in 1987.
content: Ida Nudel, who personified the Cold War struggle of Jews to immigrate from the Soviet Union to Israel, died on Tuesday in Israel, where she had lived since 1987. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Nowhere Inn’ Review: Personalities, Disordered
description: This meta exercise, starring and written by St. Vincent and Carrie Brownstein, proves its point by not having a point.
content: A hall of mirrors reflecting not terribly much, “The Nowhere Inn,” directed by Bill Benz, is an in-joke perpetrated by the singer Annie Clark, who performs as St. Vincent, and her friend and fellow musician Carrie Brownstein. The pair wrote it together and star as versions of themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Retail sales rose in August, highlighting an inconsistency of consumer spending.
description: The 0.7 percent climb in sales last month came after a 1.8 percent decline in July and gains earlier in the summer.
content: Retail sales increased slightly in August, the Commerce Department reported Thursday, highlighting an uneven pace for the economic recovery as spending behavior swings month over month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Struggle for Control of Afghanistan Comes to K Street
description: Ahmad Massoud, a leading figure in the resistance to Taliban rule, hired a lobbyist to seek military and financial support in the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — A leading figure in the Afghan resistance has retained a Washington lobbyist to seek military and financial support in the United States for a fight against the Taliban, according to a lobbying contract and a representative of the resistance leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poulos
title: How Bitcoin Can Immunize America From Cancel Culture
description: The confluence of tech and finance has produced a nascent soft social credit system. Digital currency may be the only way out.
content: Through its recent legal threat against Coinbase’s new interest-bearing cryptocurrency account program, the Securities and Exchange Commission has created a stir in both finance and tech — two worlds that have always been intertwined, but because of the implications of digital technology itself, now face each other in a deepening rivalry. Industry watchers now expect the Biden administration to go on regulatory offense against cryptocurrency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The British retailer Marks & Spencer blames Brexit as it closes French stores.
description: Getting fresh food through Brexit’s “supply chain complexities” has prompted the closing of 11 stores, the company said.
content: Marks & Spencer, the large British retailer that has been battling Brexit costs and delays for months, said on Thursday that it would close its 11 food stores in France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani and Emma Bubola
title: Italy extends its health-pass requirement to cover most workers, public and private.
description: The new mandate that workers be able to show proof of vaccination, immunity or a recent negative test by mid-October is one of the most sweeping in Europe.
content: Italy will require its residents to show a health pass to go to work, the government announced Thursday. It is the first country in Europe to require coronavirus vaccination certificates so widely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Inquiry finds World Bank officials, including now-I.M.F. chief, pushed staff to inflate China data.
description: An investigation focused on accusations that top World Bank officials pressured the team conducting an annual survey to improve China’s standing.
content: WASHINGTON — An investigation into manipulation of an annual World Bank report has found that Kristalina Georgieva, the bank’s former chief executive, who now leads the International Monetary Fund, directed staff to alter data to placate China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Berkvist
title: Jane Powell, Hollywood’s Girl Next Door, Is Dead at 92
description: Typecast from the outset, she was a star of movie musicals before she was out of her teens. But her big-screen career peaked when she was in her 20s.
content: Jane Powell, whose pert good looks and lyrical soprano voice brought her Hollywood stardom before she was out of her teens — but whose movie career peaked when she was still in her 20s with a starring role in one of the last great MGM musicals, the 1954 extravaganza “Seven Brides for Seven Brothers” — died on Thursday at her home in Wilton, Conn. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: California Housing Is a Crisis Newsom Can Take Into His Own Hands
description: Having survived a recall vote, the governor is free to focus on the state’s homeless population and housing shortage. He has more room to maneuver than he did when he first took office.
content: The median home price in California has eclipsed $800,000. Tenants in the state are among the most cost-burdened in the country. Each night more than 100,000 residents sleep outside or in their cars. A crisis, a disaster, the religion of sorrow, a disgrace — whatever journalists and politicians call it, people across the state, including all the major candidates for governor in the recall vote this week, agree that the situation is untenable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Ex-Employer of GameStop Trader ‘Roaring Kitty’ Fined for Lack of Oversight
description: The employee, Keith Gill, was also carrying out trades on behalf of three other people not affiliated with MassMutual, according to the settlement.
content: The insurer MassMutual will pay a $4 million fine as part of a settlement with Massachusetts regulators involving the conduct of Keith Gill, a former employee and online trader known as “Roaring Kitty” whose relentless cheerleading for shares of GameStop was at the heart of the meme-stock mania earlier this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Takes Lots of Jabs at Nicki Minaj
description: The rapper’s tweets about her cousin’s friend, who she said had swollen testicles after taking the Covid vaccine, set off a flood of commentary.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Cage Fighters Need Unions, Too
description: But organizing MMA fighters is a particularly tough challenge.
content: Last week in Cooperstown, N.Y., Marvin Miller, the first head of the Major League Baseball Players Association, was posthumously inducted into baseball’s Hall of Fame. No one figure, aside from Jackie Robinson, more profoundly changed American sports. When Miller, who had worked with the United Steelworkers union, began his work in baseball in 1966, the average player made $19,000 a year and was bound to the team that had first signed him — a result of a rule called the reserve clause, which placed all the power in the hands of owners to determine where a player played and how much money he made. Miller, along with Curt Flood, a center fielder for the St. Louis Cardinals who sacrificed his career for the cause, undid the reserve clause over the course of the early 1970s and ushered in the modern era of sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘My Name Is Pauli Murray’ Review: Ahead of the Times
description: The pioneering legal thinker influenced Ruth Bader Ginsburg. But this documentary by the filmmakers behind “RBG” misses the mark.
content: “My Name Is Pauli Murray,” the plainly pedagogical documentary by the filmmakers Betsy West and Julie Cohen, hinges on the audience not knowing who Murray was: an activist, writer, attorney and priest. The easier to wow us with the onslaught of information, which rightfully situates Murray — a Black, gender nonconforming intellectual who died in 1985 — as a thinker ahead of the times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Cave Featuring Native American Wall Art Is Sold to Anonymous Bidder
description: The cave, which sold for $2.2 million in St. Louis on Tuesday, is considered a sacred site by members of the Osage Nation. A tribal leader called the sale “heartbreaking.”
content: A Missouri cave considered to be the most important rock art site in North America was sold at auction on Tuesday to a private buyer, devastating leaders of the Osage Nation tribe who had hoped to buy the cave to “protect and preserve our most sacred site.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Democrats Continue to Struggle With Men of Color
description: The idea of always playing defense and never offense is, well, offensive.
content: The big headline is that the California recall failed. Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom gets to keep his job. He handily fought off the Republican challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: The Battle for Digital Privacy Is Reshaping the Internet
description: As Apple and Google enact privacy changes, businesses are grappling with the fallout, Madison Avenue is fighting back and Facebook has cried foul.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple introduced a pop-up window for iPhones in April that asks people for their permission to be tracked by different apps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera, Jon Pareles and Giovanni Russonello
title: ‘Buena Vista Social Club’ at 25: Memories of Memories
description: A group of older Cuban musicians recorded some of their favorite songs in 1996, and the album became an unlikely blockbuster. How do we hear it a quarter-century later?
content: “Buena Vista Social Club,” which was recorded 25 years ago and released in 1997, was the unlikeliest of blockbusters: a collection of decades-old Cuban songs, featuring musicians in their 60s, 70s and 80s, that has now sold in the millions worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: U.S. Seeks to Block Bankruptcy Plan That Would Free Sacklers From Opioid Claims
description: The Justice Department has been appealing the deal, approved earlier this month.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department moved on Thursday to block a bankruptcy plan that grants broad legal immunity to the pharmaceutical company Purdue Pharma, whose drug OxyContin has been at the heart of the nation’s opioid epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: A Malcolm X Opera Will Come to the Met
description: Anthony Davis’s “X,” which premiered in the 1980s, will be revived in New York in fall 2023.
content: It took 138 years for the Metropolitan Opera to present its first work by a Black composer: Terence Blanchard’s “Fire Shut Up in My Bones,” which opens its season on Sept. 27.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: In London, Musicals That Stay True to a Brand
description: “Frozen” and “Back to the Future: The Musical” are sure to please fans of the original screen works, without offering much more of interest.
content: LONDON — There’s a human story embedded within the shiny toy that is “Back to the Future: The Musical,” which opened Monday night at the Adelphi Theater here. But you pretty much know from the start that a revved-up audience is saving its greatest roar of recognition for a certain prop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About What It’s Like to Be Back in School
description: Many teenagers are back in school for the first time since March 2020. Whether they’re happy to be there or not, most agree nothing feels “normal.”
content: Welcome to the first edition of Current Events Conversation for the 2021-2022 school year. Every Thursday we editors round up some of the best teenage comments posted to our recent writing prompts, both to give those students and their schools a shout-out and to offer a snapshot of what young people around the country — and, often, around the world — are thinking about issues in the news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib and Elisabeth Egan
title: 7 New Memoirs to Read This Season
description: Look for reflections from Katie Couric, Stanley Tucci and Joy Harjo — and more.
content: As a young child, the author fled China for New York, where she and her parents were undocumented for years. Wang, now a civil rights lawyer, focuses on her early years in the United States, and how she and her family grappled with the precarity and vulnerability they faced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Death of Jihadist Behind Attack on U.S. Soldiers Is Latest Blow for Militants
description: With France’s killing of Adnan Abu Walid al-Sahraoui, experts say the Islamic State in the Greater Sahara has suffered a big loss, but caution against declaring victory.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — Even before France announced Wednesday that its forces had killed the leader of the Islamic State in the Greater Sahara, the terrorist group appeared to be struggling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sixto Cancel
title: I Will Never Forget That I Could Have Lived With People Who Loved Me
description: Group homes for foster kids have to go before more youths are harmed.
content: When I was 15, an usher at my church offered to become my foster parent. Hers was one of the best foster homes I lived in. But she wanted a son. It was more than I was able to give.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Follow the Elizabeth Holmes trial with our reporters in the courtroom.
description: The founder of Theranos is being tried on 12 counts of wire fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud. The trial is generally held Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays.
content: Erin Griffith (@eringriffith) and Erin Woo (@erinkwoo), two of our tech reporters, are covering the trial of Elizabeth Holmes, who dropped out of Stanford University to create the blood testing start-up Theranos at age 19 and built it to a $9 billion valuation and herself into the world’s youngest self-made female billionaire — only to flame out in disgrace after Theranos’s technology was revealed to have problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Jeffrey Katzenberg Talks About His Billion-Dollar Flop
description: The Hollywood mogul talks about what went wrong at Quibi and why he’s still doubling down on tech.
content: The public failure of his start-up Quibi hasn’t stopped Jeffrey Katzenberg from doubling down on tech. A Hollywood power broker, he headed up Disney in the 1980s and ’90s and co-founded a rival studio, DreamWorks, before finding a puzzle he could not yet solve: getting people to pay for short-format content. Investors gave him and the former Hewlett-Packard C.E.O. and California gubernatorial candidate Meg Whitman $1.75 billion to build a video platform, but not enough customers opened up their wallets, at $4.99 a month, and Quibi folded within a year of its launch. Katzenberg says the problems were product-market fit and the Covid pandemic, not competition from TikTok or YouTube.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman
title: Trump-Era Special Counsel Secures Indictment of Lawyer for Firm With Democratic Ties
description: The defendant, Michael Sussmann, is accused of lying to the F.B.I. in a meeting about Trump and Russia. He denies wrongdoing.
content: WASHINGTON — The special counsel appointed by the Trump administration to scrutinize the Russia investigation obtained a grand jury indictment on Thursday of a prominent cybersecurity lawyer, accusing him of lying to the F.B.I. five years ago during a meeting about Donald J. Trump and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway Is Brimming With Black Playwrights. But for How Long?
description: Theater seems to be responding to demands for diversity. Artists are both delighted and worried about the precarious moment in which the gates have opened.
content: Broadway’s prepandemic theater season featured two plays by Black writers, and one of them had been kicking around since 1981. The previous season, there was one such play, and the season before that, zero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: More people are in space right now than ever before.
description: The four-person team raised the number of people in space to 14, passing a record set in 2009.
content: Outer space got a little more crowded on Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Eileen Sullivan
title: Thousands of Afghans on American military bases await resettlement.
description: Many who left the country in August are waiting for medical and security screenings and flights from overseas that were halted by measles.
content: WASHINGTON — Weeks after their dramatic escape from Kabul, tens of thousands of Afghans hoping to be resettled in the United States remain on military bases across the country and overseas as medical and security screenings slow the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Review: In ‘Sun & Sea,’ We Laze Away the End of the World
description: Seemingly sweet yet insistently ominous, this opera installation turns a sandy beach into a spectacle of a changing climate.
content: In May 2019, as the art world raced through the first preview day of the Venice Biennale, a tiny number of us set off for a naval base in the northeast corner of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A new defense pact challenges China.
content: The U.S. and Britain announced they would help Australia deploy nuclear-powered submarines, taking a major step in challenging China’s broad territorial claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: House Panel Expands Inquiry Into Climate Disinformation by Oil Giants
description: Executives from Exxon, Shell, BP and others are being called to testify in Congress next month after a secret recording this year exposed an Exxon official boasting of such efforts.
content: The House Oversight Committee has widened its inquiry into the oil and gas industry’s role in spreading disinformation about the role of fossil fuels in causing global warming, calling on top executives from Exxon Mobil, Chevron, BP and Royal Dutch Shell, as well as the lobby groups American Petroleum Institute and the United States Chamber of Commerce, to testify before Congress next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: High natural gas prices lead to a shutdown of British fertilizer plants.
description: Companies reliant on natural gas and electricity are feeling the pinch of soaring fuel prices.
content: Manufacturers in Britain have warned in recent weeks that soaring prices for natural gas would force them to shut down factories, and that prediction is now coming true.

author: By Sebastian Modak

content: Lately I’ve found that audiobooks are keeping me up at night. It’s not because I’m devouring them in nocturnal binges, unable to tear myself away. No, I’m losing sleep because I’m thinking about certain audiobooks too much. Like a movie watched just before bed, or a video game played too many times, a good audiobook peppered throughout the day can reverberate long after you have pressed pause. Who’s the murderer? What would I do if I came face to face with a leopard? What must it have been like to be floating in the middle of the Pacific in the 16th century, scurvy-ridden and months from home? These three new audiobooks may provide some answers — but expect a fair share of mental somersaults along the way.

content: SILVER LININGS PLAYBOOK In her memoir, “Forever Young,” Hayley Mills writes about the pressures of being born into an acting family and starring in a string of box office hits as an adolescent. Mills was only 12 when she filmed her first movie, “Tiger Bay,” alongside her father, Sir John Mills; on Dec. 15, 1959, The Times described her as “one of the most composed little performers we have seen in a long time.” A year later, she played the lead in the film version of Eleanor H. Porter’s novel “Pollyanna.” “The news is that only an unregenerate cynic with an abiding dislike of kids, good or bad, Technicolor and a gentle legend spun in standard, obvious style would rail at this picture-postcard remembrance of improbable things past,” our reviewer wrote. “The blond, pixieish Miss Mills gives a restrained, natural and gratifyingly mature performance. She is a likable youngster whose mannerisms and speech are unaffected and convincing.” Mills won a special Academy Award, presented by Shirley Temple, for this role. “Forever Young” appears at No. 9 in its first week on the hardcover nonfiction list.
